title: Chapter 3 - Work and Labor
coverage: Household Service, Contract of Labor, Contract for a Piece of Work

articles.rule: Household service shall always be reasonably compensated. Any stipulation that household service is without compensation shall be void. Compensation is in addition to lodging, food, and medical attendance.

articles.topic: Provision of Lodging, Food, and Medical Attendance
articles.rule: The head of the family shall furnish, free of charge, suitable and sanitary quarters, adequate food, and medical attendance.
If the house helper is under 18, the head of the family shall provide elementary education. Its cost is part of compensation unless otherwise stipulated.
No household service contract shall last more than two years, but may be renewed yearly.
The house helper's clothes shall be subject to stipulation. Any contract preventing the house helper from affording suitable clothing is void.
The head of the family shall treat the house helper justly and humanely. Physical violence is prohibited.
House helpers shall not work more than 10 hours/day and are allowed four paid vacation days per month.
In case of death of the house helper with no local relatives, the head of the family shall bear funeral expenses if financially able.

Neither party may terminate a fixed-term contract before expiration except for just cause. Unjust dismissal entitles the house helper to earned compensation plus 15 days indemnity. Leaving without cause forfeits up to 15 days salary.
If duration is not fixed, notice periods apply depending on whether compensation is daily, weekly, or monthly.
Upon termination, the house helper may demand a written statement from the head of the family on nature, duration, efficiency, and conduct of service.
Relations between capital and labor are not merely contractual and must yield to the common good, subject to labor laws on unions, strikes, wages, and working conditions.
Neither capital nor labor shall act oppressively or impair public interest or convenience.
All labor legislation and contracts shall be construed in favor of the safety and decent living of the laborer.
No contract amounting to involuntary servitude under any guise shall be valid.
The laborer's wages shall be paid in legal currency.
Withholding wages, except for debt due, shall not be made by the employer.

articles.topic: Employer Liability for Death or Injury
articles.rule: Employers must pay compensation for death or injury arising out of employment, subject to exceptions for employee negligence or voluntary acts.

articles.topic: Contract for a Piece of Work
articles.rule: The contractor binds himself to execute a piece of work for the employer for a certain price or compensation.
The contractor shall execute work with agreed qualities and without defects. Employer may require correction or replacement at contractor's cost.
Price or compensation shall be paid at the time and place of delivery unless stipulated otherwise.

articles.topic: Responsibility for Work Done by Employees
articles.rule: The contractor is responsible for work done by persons employed by him.

articles.topic: Right to Retain Work on Movable
articles.rule: A person who has executed work on a movable has a right to retain it as pledge until payment is received.
